qas.question: What was the name of Charles Darwin's grandfather?
What theory did Erasmus Darwin outline in the 1790s?
What was the name of the scientist who developed and published a more complex version of Erasmus Darwin's theory in 1809?
What is the process of adapting to the environment and inheriting changes through use or disuse called?
Whose paleontology work in the 1790s established the reality of extinction?

context: Charles Darwin's grandfather <a0_0>Erasmus Darwin<a0_0/> outlined a <a1_0>hypothesis of transmutation of species<a1_0/> in the 1790s, and <a2_0>Jean-Baptiste Lamarck<a2_0/> published a more developed theory in 1809. Both envisaged that spontaneous generation produced simple forms of life that progressively developed greater complexity, adapting to the environment by inheriting changes in adults caused by use or disuse. This process was later called <a3_0>Lamarckism<a3_0/>. Lamarck thought there was an inherent progressive tendency driving organisms continuously towards greater complexity, in parallel but separate lineages with no extinction. Geoffroy contended that embryonic development recapitulated transformations of organisms in past eras when the environment acted on embryos, and that animal structures were determined by a constant plan as demonstrated by homologies. <a4_0>Georges Cuvier<a4_0/> strongly disputed such ideas, holding that unrelated, fixed species showed similarities that reflected a design for functional needs. His palæontological work in the 1790s had established the reality of extinction, which he explained by local catastrophes, followed by repopulation of the affected areas by other species.
